You're a wizard, Captain. - Deanna Troi

You're a wizard, Captain. - Deanna Troi

Background

OpenStax is a nonprofit textbook publisher based at Rice University, and it’s our mission to improve student access to education. Our first openly licensed college textbook was published in 2012, and our library has since grown to more than 20 books for college and AP courses used by hundreds of thousands of students.

Design is directed by an OpenStax team in collaboration with external groups and subject matter experts in their respective fields. Team participants may vary between titles under development.

Our Process

Github

The primary venue of collaboration between OpenStax and vendors is GitHub, where our code repositories and project management tools reside.

Our code repository is available (privately) at https://github.com/Connexions/oer.exports.

New collaborators

In order to gain access to the OpenStax repository, oer.exports, which holds our code and issue management tools, perform the following tasks:

  1. If you do not have a GitHub account, create one.

    • Go to http://www.github.com/.
    • Enter the requested information and click Sign up for GitHub.

  2. Send your GitHub username to Alana Lemay-Gibson nyxer@rice.edu, and Alina Slavik alinams@rice.edu.

    Our A-team will then setup your access to the Connexions / oer.exports repository. You will receive an invitation email from GitHub with a link to follow to accept access, or you may visit https://github.com/Connexions where you can find a link to accept access at the top.

  3. Visit the OpenStax repository at https://github.com/Connexions/oer.exports.

Report and track an issue with a textbook template

To submit an issue for an OpenStax textbook, perform the following tasks:

  1. Ensure that you are logged into GitHub:

    • If you are not logged into GitHub, the Sign in button displays in the upper, right corner of the page.
    • If you are logged into GitHub, your username display in the upper, right corner of the page.

  2. From the links menu on the top of the page, click Issues.

  3. Click New Issue.

  4. To create the issue, enter the following information:

    • At Title, enter a title for the issue. Please include the name of the textbook in the title, then use a colon and type a summary of the issue, e.g. "Economics: Feature titles 10 pixels too far left".
    • At no one is assigned, click the gear button and select nyxer95 to assign the issue to the Project Manager.

    • At Leave a comment, enter the following information:

      1. Rendition in which you encountered the issue, e.g. HTML, PDF, etc.
      2. Chapter and Module number.
      3. A detailed (quantitative and qualitative) description of the issue.

    • At Add Labels, click to select a value from all of the following label groups:

      1. book
      2. env
      3. prio
      4. type

    • Locate the screen captures of the issue and drag them into the comment section of the page.

      To ensure that your screen captures are inserted properly, click Preview.

    • Click Submit new issue

To track issues that you submitted, perform the following tasks:

  1. Go to https://github.com/Connexions/oer.exports/issues?state=open.

  2. From Browse Issues, click Created by you.

  3. If you want to see only the issues related to a specific book, click one of the book labels.

Questions

If you have any questions about how to use GitHub to track issues related to OpenStax textbook development, please contact the Project Manager for OpenStax, Alana Lemay-Gibson, at nxyer@rice.edu

Report and track an issue with this document.

Content servers

A list of our servers and their purposes is available in our Textbook Team Servers document.

Report an issue with a content development staging server.

  1. Complete the following email template:
  2. Subject Line: URGENT: Work Stoppage on Textbook Staging Server

  3. Message Body: We don't have access to the server at address: _____________. It has been down for __ [minutes/hour(s)]. This is causing work stoppage.

  4. Include a brief statement of the nature of the outage (text or screenshot of the error message, etc.).

  5. Email the completed template to [partner name]@openstax.org.

Cc other members of your team as appropriate.

Limitations

One of our methods of improving access to education is lowering cost, and in our effort to do so we have adopted methods of textbook production which many may find unfamiliar. We rely heavily on technology that provides automated content layout and composition for print. This allows us to quickly change content and style, but it also leads to many unique problems. We will investigate some of those problems in detail.

A list of GitHub Issues which relate to these platform limitations is maintained using a status:wontfix label.

Page count

A large factor in textbook cost is the length of the text, and we have made the decision to sacrifice the quality of our layout and composition in order to lower student cost by reducing page count. This means that if a text is too long to print, we will adjust the style to lower the page count -- usually resulting in a lower quality textbook. Vertical space is extremely valuable, and should never be wasted. With regards to breaking this rule, only the most vital pedagogical features will be considered.

Our hardcover textbooks are limited to 1700 pages. We prefer a page count considerably lower, to increase accessibility and affordability.

While we acknowledge that white space, or negative space, is an active element in a good design, we have traded manual control of this type of pixel-perfect layout for software algorithms that place content into a paged layout quickly. This means that adding or removing whitespace can be difficult, or impossible, especially where content breaks across pages or where it has been set into multiple columns.

Column Layouts

Only specific content, such as collated material, can be organized into columns. The primary body text of each chapter is limited to one column. Markup and instruction will be provided in a tagging legend if a title supports organizing content into a column layout.

Text wrapping

Our renderer does not support wrapping text around images.

Math and scientific notation

Our publishing platform does not completely support the features of the MathML language. We cannot use colors, certain roots outside the radical, or many features of vertical math. We have documented MathML Guidelines to help avoid some of these problems or introducing others.

Page breaking

  • Any kind of forced page breaks should be kept to a minimum. Without the ability to control placement of each piece of content individually, forcing elements such as tables or other varying length content to break will lead to unintended white space on a page and potentially increase page count significantly. Limiting forced page breaks also helps avoid problems if content is reused.
  • Chapters, appendices, and some collated material will appear after an automatic page break that will force such content to appear on an odd, right hand side, page.
  • Content is allowed to break within tables unless otherwise specified.
  • Content is allowed to break inside a feature unless otherwise specified.
  • Restrictions to natural content breaks may occur in exercises, examples, or other content. End of chapter material might have specific page breaking rules to ensure that exercise titles remain with the exercise problems. Sometimes breaks will be forced so that exercises flow evenly when in columns. These typically depend on the complexity of the layout and/or content.
GENERAL COMPOSITION

Color

OpenStax textbooks are primarily in four subjects Mathematics, Science, Business, and Humanities. We specify four general "themes" that specify the style for our titles in these markets.

Themes

Mathematics

Science

Business

Humanities

Source Art

Source art should use colors from the primary palette from a specific markets theme.

Typography

A double-stranded scale (Perfect Fifth and Perfect Fourth) is used to determine text sizes. Vertical space, padding or margin, will be determined using a method that will ensure that all text is composed in such a way that vertical space is divided into portions equal in height to the product of font size and line height.

All text will land on a vertical position that is an integer multiple of (base font size * base line height). Base font size, as well as line height, can be changed during production for a number of reasons, the most common being textbook length. Longer titles may require text to have less line height, or a smaller font size. Limiting text sizes to specific ratios, and determining vertical spaces relative to that text size, ensures that we can change text properties in a predicatable way. All vertical spaces will adjust at the same ratios as text sizes change.

Fonts

Our books generally use a combination of Noto Sans, Noto Serif, and Dosis.

  • Noto Sans, Noto Serif
  • Dosis, Noto Sans
  • Dosis, Noto Serif

Mathematics

Mathematics is rendered using STIX Fonts Project fonts. These fonts are licensed SIL Open Font License (OFL-1.1).

Page Layout

Page dimensions are 8.5 x 11 inches. Top and bottom margins are 0.8 inch, left and right margins are 1 inch.

The page is split into margins, folio (page header and footer), and a content area. Numbers and generated content (such as surrent page number, current chapter title, etc) can appear in the folio areas. An attribution link is automatically added to the footer of all even-numbered pages.

Image Layout

We support full width, two column, and three column sets of images and figures. The composition rules for images and for problem/solution sets are the same.

)
